title: VP Mike Pence backs inquiries into Biden, defends President Trump over Ukraine controversy
text:
CLOSE Vice President Mike Pence on Oct. 3, 2019, says ties between his predecessor in office and Ukraine should be investigated. Brian Snyder, Arizona Republic

SCOTTSDALE, Ariz. – Vice President Mike Pence defended President Donald Trump's request to ask Ukraine's president to investigate political rival Joe Biden and his son during an appearance Thursday in Scottsdale.

Pence's comments came after The Washington Post detailed the many ways Pence has been pulled into the controversy that has engulfed the White House over Trump's efforts to pressure Ukraine's president for damaging information on Biden, the former vice president and now a leading Democratic candidate for president, and Biden's son, Hunter.

"The American people have the right to know if the vice president of the United States or his family profited from his position as vice president during the last administration," Pence said. "That's about looking backwards and understanding what really happened."

Pence said when he met last month with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky at the request of Trump, they spoke of the lack of support from European partners against Russian aggression and "real issues of corruption in Ukraine." The American people deserve to know that any aid money going to the country from the U.S. is going towards a government "free of corruption," he said.

"Those were the that topics we discussed," Pence told reporters. "And that was all we discussed. The simple truth is, that those are the same issues that the president raised with President Zelensky during that call."

Pence lashed out against Democrats in the House of Representatives who have launched an impeachment inquiry to examine the extent of Trump's dealings with Ukraine.

"This is just more of the same of what we've seen from Democrats over the last two and a half years," he said. "These endless investigations should end in Washington, D.C."

Asked about his message to voters who are troubled that Trump has asked a foreign leader to investigate a domestic political foe, Pence told The Arizona Republic's political podcast, The Gaggle, that the Bidens' involvement in Ukraine "represents an issue the American people are entitled to know more about and to get to the bottom of and get to the facts of."

CLOSE Vice President Mike Pence on Thursday addressed his meeting with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky. Brian Snyder, Arizona Republic

Arizona Senate race looms

Pence's comments on Ukraine and the impeachment inquiry came on a trip intended to highlight the administration's economic achievements and to strengthen the campaign prospects of Sen. Martha McSally, R-Ariz, who was appointed to the Senate and faces election in 2020. He headlined a private fundraiser for her Wednesday night in Paradise Valley.

Pence praised McSally's time in the Senate, saying she has quickly emerged a "preeminent leader" in the GOP-led Senate.

"I truly believe that in the days ahead, as we bring our campaign back to Arizona, you're going to see the Trump-Pence team win the day again in Arizona," Pence told The Gaggle. "And I think you're going to see Martha McSally elected for six more years."

At a downtown Scottsdale church Thursday morning, Pence, McSally, Republican Gov. Doug Ducey and U.S. Treasurer Jovita Carranza participated in a roundtable discussion with Latino business owners and leaders, conservative officials and school-choice advocates to celebrate the contributions of Latinos during Hispanic Heritage Month.

Pence, McSally and Ducey emphasized the benefits of the economy under Trump to Hispanic-owned businesses and workers, especially Hispanic women.

"So it's an exciting time in our economy," Pence said at First Baptist Church of Scottsdale with Ducey on his right and McSally on his left. "And as we begin Hispanic Heritage Month, it's a particularly exciting time for jobs and opportunities for Hispanic Americans, not just in a growing state like Arizona, but, really, all across the country."
